column4: can anyone get me sorted on the syntax of using umount to unmount a network resource that's mounted to (at least according to nautilus) ~/.gvfs/media on 10.0.0.10  ?  i don't understand the docs D:
If you mount it via gvfs ( nautilus ) you need to unmount it via gvfs
does that mean i can't use a terminal command, but must use nautilus?
There is probably a way to do it via ther terminal but I don't know what that is

the issue i have is that a home backup script yanks the contents of a 2tb network share if i forget to unmount it first.  i'd like to be able to have a umount command or equivalent in the script as a safety net
You should make your script stay within a single file system
it runs a series of rsync commands
rsync can stay within a file system
but doesn't gvfs fuse throw that off?
yeah i tried to exclude ~/.gvfs but it didn't seem to work, i must not understand what i'm reading on doc sites
ok i'll try that now and see, thanks
wow that was great!  don't know how i overlooked that flag (if it was in the docs i read anyways).  thanks, you just saved me a ton of grief
np, it was in the ( very long ) man page, I had the advantage of knowing what to look for :)
